articles.title: A black hole fell into a star – then ate its way out again
articles.summary: Stars often fall into black holes, and now it seems the opposite can also occur, producing an extra long-lasting explosion as the star is consumed from within
articles.content:
Stars often fall into black holes, and now it seems the opposite can also occur, producing an extra long-lasting explosion as the star is consumed from within

This orange dot is a gamma-ray burst that seems to be a sign of an unusual event ESO/A. Levan, A. Martin-Carrillo et al.

A black hole that was eaten by a star seems to have gotten revenge by consuming the star from the inside, producing a gamma-ray burst spotted about 9 billion light-years from Earth.

The burst, called GRB 250702B, was first spotted by NASA’s Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope in July. Such bursts are bright flashes caused by jets fired out from energetic events, such as massive stars collapsing into black holes or neutron stars merging, and they usually last no more than a few minutes.

GRB 250702B, however, lasted for 25,000 seconds – or about 7 hours – making it the longest-known gamma-ray burst. Scientists had struggled to explain it, but Eliza Neights at NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Centre in the US and her colleagues now suggest an unusual and rare possibility.

“The only [model] which naturally explains the properties observed in GRB 250702B is the fall of a stellar-mass black hole into a star,” the researchers write in a paper about their work.

In more-typical long gamma-ray bursts, a massive star collapses to form a black hole, launching jets as it dies. In this case, the team suggests the reverse – a pre-existing black hole spiralled into a companion star whose outer layers had expanded late in its life, causing the black hole to lose angular momentum and fall towards the star’s core.

Subscriber-only newsletter Sign up to Lost in Space-Time Untangle mind-bending physics, maths and the weirdness of reality with our monthly, special-guest-written newsletter. Sign up to newsletter

The black hole would then have consumed the star from the inside-out, producing the powerful jets seen as GRB 250702B and possibly triggering a faint supernova, albeit one that was too dim to detect at this distance, even with the James Webb Space Telescope.

This explanation makes sense for how an ultra-long burst like this might occur, says Hendrik van Eerten at the University of Bath in the UK. “The argument posed in this paper is a very compelling one,” he says.

Neights and her colleagues hope that more events like this might be observed in the future, thanks to upcoming telescopes like the Vera Rubin Observatory in Chile. For now, this gamma ray burst remains “an absurdity”, says Van Eerten.

This breakthrough advances our understanding of cosmic phenomena, has broad significance for astrophysics, and is supported by detailed research and expert commentary.
articles.personality_title: Scientists explain longest gamma-ray burst as black hole falling into star
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Gamma-ray bursts are bright flashes in space caused by energetic events like stars collapsing or neutron stars merging. They usually last only a few minutes.

**What happened** – In July, NASA’s Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope spotted a gamma-ray burst named GRB 250702B that lasted about 7 hours, much longer than any seen before. Scientists led by Eliza Neights suggest this happened because a small black hole fell into a large star and then ate the star from inside.

**Impact** – This is the first time researchers have explained such an ultra-long burst with this rare event. It changes how scientists think about black holes and stars interacting. The black hole’s fall into the star and its slow consumption from within created the long-lasting burst of energy.

**What's next step** – Scientists hope to find more of these unusual bursts using new telescopes like the Vera Rubin Observatory in Chile. Studying more events will help confirm this discovery and improve our understanding of extreme cosmic phenomena.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A rare event where a black hole fell into a star explains the longest gamma-ray burst ever observed, opening new insights into cosmic explosions.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les scientifiques expliquent le plus long sursaut gamma par un trou noir tombant dans une étoile
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les sursauts gamma sont des éclairs lumineux dans l’espace causés par des événements énergétiques comme l’effondrement d’étoiles ou la fusion d’étoiles à neutrons. Ils durent en général seulement quelques minutes.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En juillet, le télescope spatial Fermi de la NASA a détecté un sursaut gamma nommé GRB 250702B qui a duré environ 7 heures, bien plus longtemps que tous ceux observés auparavant. Des scientifiques dirigés par Eliza Neights pensent que cela s’est produit parce qu’un petit trou noir est tombé dans une grande étoile puis l’a consommée de l’intérieur.

**Impact** – C’est la première fois que des chercheurs expliquent un sursaut aussi long par cet événement rare. Cela change la façon dont les scientifiques comprennent les interactions entre trous noirs et étoiles. La chute du trou noir dans l’étoile et sa consommation lente ont créé cette émission d’énergie prolongée.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques espèrent détecter d’autres sursauts inhabituels grâce à de nouveaux télescopes comme l’Observatoire Vera Rubin au Chili. Étudier plus d’événements aidera à confirmer cette découverte et à mieux comprendre ces phénomènes cosmiques extrêmes.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Un événement rare où un trou noir est tombé dans une étoile explique le plus long sursaut gamma jamais observé, ouvrant de nouvelles perspectives sur les explosions cosmiques.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos explican el estallido de rayos gamma más largo como un agujero negro cayendo en una estrella
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los estallidos de rayos gamma son destellos brillantes en el espacio causados por eventos energéticos como el colapso de estrellas o la fusión de estrellas de neutrones. Usualmente duran solo unos minutos.

**Qué pasó** – En julio, el telescopio espacial Fermi de la NASA detectó un estallido de rayos gamma llamado GRB 250702B que duró unas 7 horas, mucho más que cualquier otro visto antes. Científicos liderados por Eliza Neights sugieren que esto ocurrió porque un pequeño agujero negro cayó dentro de una estrella grande y luego la consumió desde adentro.

**Impacto** – Es la primera vez que los investigadores explican un estallido ultra largo con este raro evento. Esto cambia cómo los científicos piensan sobre la interacción entre agujeros negros y estrellas. La caída del agujero negro y su consumo lento dentro de la estrella crearon el estallido prolongado de energía.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos esperan encontrar más de estos estallidos inusuales usando nuevos telescopios como el Observatorio Vera Rubin en Chile. Estudiar más eventos ayudará a confirmar este descubrimiento y a mejorar la comprensión de fenómenos cósmicos extremos.

**Resumen en una frase** – Un evento raro donde un agujero negro cayó dentro de una estrella explica el estallido de rayos gamma más largo observado, abriendo nuevas ideas sobre explosiones cósmicas.
